survey.name: Tapestry Research
survey.res: Please write your answer in the box below.
Please select one answer for each item.
Please enter a number in the box below.
You have already stated that you are a parent, please select an answer below.
You’ve said that you have a PVR/DVR but not a TV. Please check your responses.

You’ve said ${'you' if DUM_INTERVIEW_TYPE.r1 or DUM_INTERVIEW_TYPE.r4 else 'they'} did NONE of these in this time period. Is this correct? If so just click the arrow to continue. If not, please check your answers!
Not at all – it wouldn’t make a difference if ${'I' if DUM_INTERVIEW_TYPE.r1 or DUM_INTERVIEW_TYPE.r4 else 'they'} couldn’t do it at times like this

Lots – ${'I' if DUM_INTERVIEW_TYPE.r1 or DUM_INTERVIEW_TYPE.r4 else 'they'} would really miss it if ${'I' if DUM_INTERVIEW_TYPE.r1 or DUM_INTERVIEW_TYPE.r4 else 'they'} couldn’t do it at times like this
Not important at all – it wouldn’t make a difference what ${'I' if DUM_INTERVIEW_TYPE.r1 or DUM_INTERVIEW_TYPE.r4 else 'they'} used
Extremely important – it had to be exactly the right thing
Not important at all – wouldn’t be dissapointed if it disappeared entirely!
Extremely important – really value being able to ${DUM_ACTION.selected.text} it
Not at all, it definitely couldn’t give ${'me what I wanted' if DUM_INTERVIEW_TYPE.r1 or DUM_INTERVIEW_TYPE.r4 else 'them what they wanted'}
It definitely could have given ${'me what I wanted' if DUM_INTERVIEW_TYPE.r1 or DUM_INTERVIEW_TYPE.r4 else 'them what they wanted'}
Impossible, nothing from the BBC could have given ${'me what I wanted' if DUM_INTERVIEW_TYPE.r1 or DUM_INTERVIEW_TYPE.r4 else 'them what they wanted'}
Very easy, something from the BBC would definitely have worked for this occasion
I never consume any of this through the BBC
All (or almost all) of my BBC use for this content is offline (broadcast TV, DAB radio, print newspapers, etc). I almost never consume this online.
All (or almost all) of my BBC use for this content is online through apps or sites. I almost never consume this offline.

So far, you've said you haven't done any of these activities. If that’s correct then OK! You told us you did these things at least once in the last 24 hours, however, so please keep thinking carefully about your answers!

A session is one period of time on the same service. So if you spent 20 minutes reading news on your phone, that’s a ‘session’. If you also then spent five minutes checking the news headlines in the same part of the day, that would be two ‘sessions’ in total – the 20 minute one and then a five minute one a bit later.

As another example, if you watched something on TV live, as it was broadcast on ITV1 and then watched the thing that followed it, that would be one ‘session’. If you then switched to Disney+ to watch something else, that would make it two ‘sessions’ – you’re changing the service you use, so that makes it a new ‘session’.

radio.label: TEEN_CONSENT
radio.title:
We are interested in the views of 12-15 year olds on media, the things they use and why they use it.

This study is being conducted across the UK to understand the thoughts and opinions of kids and teens aged 12-15 along with people aged 16 and above. The survey should take no longer than 20 minutes to complete. The survey is a little complicated in places so they may need help with some questions.

Would you give permission for a kid or teen in your household aged 12-15 years old to take part in this online research?

radio.label: TEEN_SELECT
radio.title:
Are they with you now? If you have more than one kid or teen in the household aged 12-15 years, please think about the one who is available and whose birthday is nearest to today.

Which teen aged 12-15 is available to take the survey?

radio.label: OLDERKID_CONSENT
radio.title:
We are interested in the views of 8-11 year olds on media, the things they use and why they use it.

This study is being conducted across the UK to understand the thoughts and opinions of kids aged 8-11 along with older people. The survey should take no longer than 20 minutes to complete.

The survey is a little complicated in places and is probably too much for a child aged 8-11 to complete themselves. We would really appreciate it if you could sit with your child and do the survey on their behalf, asking them what they think when it is relevant.

Would you give permission for your child to participate with you in this way, while you complete the survey with them on their behalf?

radio.label: OLDERKID_SELECT
radio.title:
Are they with you now? If you have more than one kid in the household aged 8-11 years, please think about the one who is available and whose birthday is nearest to today.

Which kid aged 8-11 is available to take the survey?

radio.label: YOUNGERKID_CONSENT
radio.title:
We are interested in the views of 4-7 year olds on media, the things they use and why they use it.

This study is being conducted across the UK to understand the thoughts and opinions of kids along with older people. The survey should take no longer than 20 minutes to complete.

It’s very unlikely that a child of this age could complete the survey! We would really appreciate it if you try to answer the survey on their behalf, thinking about what they do and why they do it. Feel free to sit with your child while you do this and ask them if you think they can help, of course!

Would you be happy to complete the survey on behalf of your child aged 4-7?

radio.label: YOUNGERKID_SELECT
radio.title: Which child will you think about when completing this survey? If you have more than one kid in the household aged 4-7 years, please think about the one whose birthday is nearest to today.

block.html: Thank you! Please hand over to your [pipe: DUM_SELECTED_CHILD lower] to answer the rest of the survey.

Thank you! Please ask your [pipe: DUM_SELECTED_CHILD lower] to sit with you as you answer the survey on their behalf.

Remember, unless we say otherwise, we want you to answer as if your [pipe: DUM_SELECTED_CHILD lower] was answering!

Thank you! Please answer the survey on behalf of your [pipe: DUM_SELECTED_CHILD lower]. If they can sit with you and help you at any point, that’s great. They don’t have to and, obviously, younger kids won’t really be that much help in answering the questions!

Remember, unless we say otherwise, we want you to answer as if your [pipe: DUM_SELECTED_CHILD lower] was answering!

radio.label: TEEN_CONSENT_2
radio.title:
Hi! Thanks for taking part in our survey. We are interested in the views of teens like you on media, the things you use and why you use it. It shouldn’t take you longer than 20 minutes to fill in.

Do you wish to continue?

autofill.label: DUM_DO_YOU_OR_YOUR_CHILD
autofill.title: 'do you' / 'do you or your child' pipe

define.label: DEVICES_LIST
define.row: TV set (a 'normal' TV set that does not connect directly to the internet e.g. Freesat, Freeview etc.)
Smart TV (i.e. 'internet-connected TV' that connects directly to the internet to stream online video without needing a separate device)
Portable gaming console (e.g. Nintendo Switch, PlayStation Vita etc.)
VR (Virtual Reality) headset (e.g. Google Cardboard, Oculus Rift)
Recording box/hard disk recorder, sometimes called a PVR/DVR which can record TV programmes and allows you to pause or rewind live TV (e.g. Sky Q etc.)
Device for streaming or casting online content to your TV set (e.g. Chromecast, Roku Streaming Stick— but not including video game consoles)
Smartphone (this is a phone on which you can download apps and access email, the internet etc., e.g. iPhone, Samsung Galaxy)
Tablet (e.g. iPad, Samsung Galaxy Tab, Microsoft Surface Pro etc.)
Voice activated device capable of playing video (e.g. Amazon Echo Show)
Smart speaker (e.g. Sonos One, Amazon Echo, Google Nest etc.)
Smart watch (e.g. Apple Watch, Garmin, Fitbit etc.)

define.label: DEVICES_LIST_SHORTENED_FOR_PIPING
define.row: A device for streaming or casting online content to your TV
A voice activated device capable of playing video

checkbox.label: DEVICES
checkbox.title: Which, if any, of these devices [pipe: DUM_DO_YOU_DOES_YOUR_CHILD] use in a typical week? Please read the answers carefully and make sure you select ALL that apply.

Thanks!

We would like you to think about the things [pipe: DUM_YOU_HAVE_YOUR_CHILD_HAS] done in the last 24 hours.

We will start from the beginning of that 24 hour period and work forwards towards the most recent time period. Don’t worry, we will not go hour-by-hour. We’re going to ask you about the time periods below:

Thanks! It’s really helpful to know how [pipe: DUM_YOU_USE_YOUR_CHILD_USES] these services and what [pipe: DUM_YOU_HAVE_YOUR_CHILD_HAS] been up to over the last 24 hours.

Now we would like to focus on ONE specific occasion in which [pipe: DUM_YOU_YOUR_CHILD] used some media.

This is when [pipe: DUM_YOU_YOUR_CHILD]:

  • [pipe: DUM_TYPE]
  • Which was: [pipe: DUM_TITLE]
  • At: [pipe: DUM_TIME]
  • On: [pipe: DUM_DAY]
Remember, unless we say otherwise, we want you to answer on behalf of your [pipe: DUM_SELECTED_CHILD]!

block.html:
Most of these questions are still about your [pipe: DUM_SELECTED_CHILD]. We really want to know why THEY were [pipe: DUM_ACTIVITY] this [pipe: DUM_ITEM].

It might be quite hard to know exactly what they wanted or why they did something, but try your best to put yourself in their place. You can ask them too, if you think it will be helpful.

There are one or two questions that we do want your own views, however. We’ll try to be really clear when those appear!

radio.label: B3_PARENT1
radio.title:
We will begin with a question about YOU, not your child!

Was it YOUR decision for your child to do something at this point or did they decide to do it themselves?
radio.row: It was mostly my decision but they had some influence
It was mostly my child's decision but I had some influence
It was entirely my child's decision

checkbox.row: So I could get something else done
So I could have a better time
So I could enjoy what I wanted to do
Just to make my life easier!

radio.label: B3_PARENT3
radio.title: How much did you know what they were actually [pipe: DUM_ACTIVITY] at this time?

block.html:
Thanks! That was a very long section but hopefully it wasn’t too much effort.

We would now like to focus on the specific [pipe: DUM_ITEM] [pipe: DUM_YOU_YOUR_CHILD] [pipe: DUM_ACTION] at this time, which is:

[pipe: DUM_TITLE]

Remember, we’re still thinking about [pipe: DUM_ACTIVITY] it at this specific time!

  • At: [pipe: DUM_TIME]
  • On: [pipe: DUM_DAY]
Again, unless we say otherwise, we want you to answer on behalf of your [pipe: DUM_SELECTED_CHILD]!

block.label: SECTION_E
block.builder:title: Section E
block.html: Thanks again for your help today. We’ve two more short sections. The last section will be a quick look at some more background information for you, as we need to make sure we’re talking to a really wide range of people.

radio.label: DUM_SEC_E_PLATFORM
radio.title: Section E Platform

block.html:
Before that, in this short section we would like you to think about ONE of the specific brands or platforms [pipe: DUM_YOU_YOUR_CHILD] might have used.

This is: [pipe: DUM_SEC_E_PLATFORM] and the BBC in general.

radio.title: USED RELEVANT BBC PLATFORM [pipe: DUM_SEC_E_PLATFORM] IN CHOSEN OCCASION?
radio.exec:
clearQ(thisQuestion, "sp")
platform_label = PLATFORM.selected.label
sounds_match = DUM_SEC_E_PLATFORM.r1 and platform_label == p.bbc_sounds_code news_match = DUM_SEC_E_PLATFORM.r2 and platform_label == p.bbc_news_code sport_match = DUM_SEC_E_PLATFORM.r3 and platform_label == p.bbc_sport_code iplayer_match = DUM_SEC_E_PLATFORM.r4 and platform_label == p.bbc_iplayer_code
if sounds_match or news_match or sport_match or iplayer_match: thisQuestion.val = thisQuestion.r1.index else: thisQuestion.val = thisQuestion.r2.index

block.html:
Thanks very much for trying to put yourself in your child’s place and tell us why they do what they do. We know it must have been hard in some places!

From this point on we would like you to answer on your own behalf. These are questions for you and about you!

number.label: BBC_RATING
number.title:
Thinking about the BBC as a whole - the TV programmes, radio stations, websites and apps, and the sort of organisation the BBC is and the way it goes about providing a public service broadcasting service. Overall, what do you think of the BBC?

Please give a score from 1 to 10, where 1 is ’Extremely unfavourable’, and 10 is ‘Extremely favourable’.

radio.label: BBC4M
radio.title: Thinking about the BBC and everything you get from it, how much do you agree or disagree with what’s being said below?
radio.row: The BBC has a lot to offer me

define.label: BBC_DAYS_LIST

Watch iPlayer (either online, via an app or through your set-top box or TV)
Listen to BBC radio via a radio (e.g. BBC Radio 1, Radio 2, Radio 3, Radio 4, 5live, 1Xtra, Asian Network, 6 Music, 4Extra, BBC Radio for your part of the UK)
Listen to something through BBC Sounds (either the app or through the website)
Use BBC websites/apps apart from BBC Sounds or iPlayer (e.g. BBC News Online, BBC Sport Online, BBC Bitesize, BBC Food Online, BBC Weather Online, BBC Homepage, BBC Children's Online, BBC Three)

radio.row: I am partially responsible and share the cost with others
I/we are given it for free as somebody in the household is over 75 and receives pension credit
I/we don't have a TV licence

radio.label: LICENCE_VIEW
radio.title: Thinking about what the TV Licence fee gives you access to, which of the below best describes your intentions to continue paying over the next 6 months?
radio.exec: thisQuestion.rows.order = [4,3,2,1,0]
radio.row: I have already decided to stop paying
I am seriously thinking of stopping paying
I will continue to pay for now, but doubting it's worth it
I will continue to pay and its somewhat worth it
I will continue to pay and it's very much worth it.

number.label: VFM
number.title:
The TV licence fee pays for all BBC services across TV, iPlayer, radio and online. It costs £159 a year, or £13.25 a month, and needs to be paid by every household that watches broadcast TV or uses iPlayer. Thinking about any BBC programmes you and your household watch on TV or iPlayer, any BBC radio stations listened to, as well as any BBC websites or apps used.

To what extent do you think the licence fee is value for money?

block.label: DEMOGRAPHICS
block.html:
Thanks! We know this has been a long survey.

We’re very close to the end now. These last questions are just to make sure we’re talking to a wide range of people. Thanks for sticking with us!

radio.title: How often, if at all, do you read the following?
radio.comment: Please select one answer for each of the following, and think about how you read across different devices

radio.label: UKX3
radio.cardsort:cardCSS: font-family: 'Century Gothic', CenturyGothic, AppleGothic, sans-serif; max-width: 950px;
radio.title:
Thinking about why you watch television, how much do you agree or disagree with the following statements.
Please select one answer for each of the following, and think about how you watch television across different screens and devices

I watch television...
radio.row: To relax and de-stress from the pressures of the day
To make me feel happy and put a smile on my face
To watch something familiar I knew I'd enjoy
To watch something that's a guilty pleasure of mine
To learn how to do something (e.g. cooking, DIY, etc.)
To watch something that takes me on an emotional journey
To lose myself in another world
To watch something with cinema-like production quality
To watch something with famous actors
To avoid feeling like I'm missing out on something

define.label: GAMING_P12M_LIST
define.row: Played or downloaded a free-to-play video game
Played a game online with your real-life friends
Watched a live gaming stream (e.g. on Twitch, YouTube Gaming, PandaTV etc)
Watched an esports tournament (Organized multiplayer video game competitions)
Used a subscription service such as XBOX LIVE, PlayStation Plus or Steam
Played a game using cloud gaming platform/streaming service (i.e. Steam/Playstation Now/Google Stadia)
Shared an image/video of your gameplay online
Purchased a video game from an online store/digital platform (i.e. Steam/Origin/Epic)
Purchased an in-game item/feature using a micro-transaction (e.g. character skins, in-game upgrades)
Purchased a game add-on or DLC
Broadcast a live stream of your gameplay

checkbox.label: GAMING_P12M
checkbox.title: Which of these have you done in the last 12 months?

checkbox.label: GAMING_PM
checkbox.title: Which of these have you done in the last month?

radio.label: STD_EDUCATION
radio.title: What is the highest level of formal education you have completed to date or expect to complete (if you’re still studying)?
radio.row: A few years of secondary education

autofill.label: DUM_X1_EXTRA_TEXT
autofill.title: X1 extra text
autofill.row: If you’re still at school, simply tell us what type of school you go to right now!

radio.label: X1
radio.title: Which of the following best describes the type of school you attended? If you attended more than one, please think about where you spent the majority of your secondary education (i.e. ages 11 – 16). [pipe: DUM_X1_EXTRA_TEXT]

radio.label: STD_EMPLOYMENT
radio.title: Which of the following best describes your employment status?
radio.row: Employed – full-time (30 hours or more a week)
Self-employed – full-time (30 hours or more a week)

radio.label: DUM_EMPLOYMENT_STATUS
radio.title: HIDDEN VARIABLE TO CODE FROM ‘EMPLOYMENT’

checkbox.label: X2
checkbox.title: Do you currently receive state benefits for any of the following?

radio.label: STD_SOC_ALT
radio.title: Please select the category which best describes the occupation of the main income earner in your household. If the main income earner is now retired, please select the category that would have applied before they retired.
radio.row: Very senior manager in business or commerce
Principal officer in local government or civil service
Public service (police, health, education, fire service)
Middle management executive in large organisation
Non-manual worker e.g. clerical, secretarial or sales
Skilled manual worker e.g. electrician, hairdresser, train driver
Manual worker with responsibility for other people
Semi-skilled manual worker e.g. security guard, catering staff
Apprentice or trainee to skilled workers

radio.label: DUM_SOC_GRADE
radio.title: HIDDEN VARIABLE TO CODE SOCIAL GRADE FROM SOC_ALT

block.html: On the next few screens we’d like to ask about your parents

Principal officer in local government or civil service
Public service (police, health, education, fire service)

Non-manual worker e.g., clerical, secretarial or sales
Skilled manual worker e.g., electrician, hairdresser, train driver
